string_table.name: npnxnanbnsnfns10111101111
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

search.slidetext: accessible course for screen reader testing select shift + ? to see a list of keyboard shortcuts for muting the course, adjusting accessibility features and navigating through the course. begin course begin course begin course begin course begin course begin course when to use auto-jump: if you already gave instructions to your sr users and you plan to begin audio on the second slide. you do not need auto-jump if: you plan to have your first slide silent.

accessible course for screen reader testing select shift + ? to see a list of keyboard shortcuts for muting the course, adjusting accessibility features and navigating through the course. select begin course when you’re ready. begin course begin course begin course begin course begin course begin course hello and welcome to this course on accessibility. before we get started, you should be aware of a few keyboard shortcuts you can use during this course. on your keyboard, select shift, windows and the question mark keys at anytime to view a full list of shortcuts. one shortcut that will be most useful to those using a screen reader will be the mute option, which is ctrl + alt + m. muting the course now will prevent you from hearing the narration that will begin playing on the next slide. if you’re using a screen reader, you will use the up and down arrows to move through the onscreen objects. occasionally, there will be a glitch and the screen reader will skip elements on the page and jump to the middle or bottom of the page or into the navigation. in that case, use the up or down arrow key until you reach the button called back to top. selecting that button will reset the slide and move you to the top of the page so you can view all of the content. when you’re ready, select begin course.
welcome! welcome to our accessible course that has been completely redesigned to accommodate all types of learners.

video setting: tania is moving her hands around as she talks video transcript: hey! do you wanna learn how to make your e-learning courses more accessible? are you working on a course that needs to be 508 compliant? does your course need to prevent discrimination based on ada? then this course is for you! in this course you’re going to learn about all the standards and how to implement them in storyline. you’ll see specific examples and i’ll walk you through exactly what to do to make your courses are 508 compliant, which also meets the wcag aa standards, which by default, will also make your course ada compliant. i got resources. i got videos. i got tips and tricks. you need this course to take your career to the next level. come on! sign up now!

section 1 e-learning accessibility guidelines accessibility definition standards and guidelines disability statistics in section 1 you will learn what accessibility is, the standards and guidelines used to be sure we have achieved accessibility and you will learn a fascinating disability statistic.

developer notes you will have to hide the comic strip in order to adjust things. you will also have to move things up/down on the tl in order to edit efficiently. captions and people should have a fade transition. let’s create a course. it must be accessible. but how? wcag guidelines! wcag guidelines are helpful. wcag guidelines are helpful for making e-learning courses accessible. (conversation) girl: let’s create a course. boy: it must be accessible. girl: but how? boy: wcag guidelines!

wcag are universal guidelines for meeting ada and 508 requirements. 508 applies to the digital assets of federal agencies and those receiving federal funds. ada is a law that applies to public entities that requires all physical and digital structures to be accessible. developer notes add content to each layer. if you add additional layers, you will need to adjust the triggers for the arrow icons to include the new layer. what the standards? use the arrows to learn about all three. there are three big players in the accessibility world. next slide next slide next slide next slide next slide next slide

that’s incorrect! ada and 508 are laws that require certain entities to create products that are accessible to everyone. wcag contains guidelines on how to meet the requirements. continue continue continue continue continue continue ada and 508 are laws that require certain entities to create products that are accessible to everyone. wcag contains guidelines on how to meet the requirements. that’s correct! continue continue continue continue continue continue ada wcag 508 applies to federal agencies applies to all public entities guidelines for meeting requirements knowledge check developer notes add feedback to the actual slide layers and not on the question itself. you can add more answer options using the form view. drag and drop the descriptions to the proper term and select submit when you are done. submit submit submit submit submit submit this is a drag and drop. please skip. this is a drag and drop. please skip. this is a drag and drop. please skip. this is a drag and drop. please skip. this is a drag and drop. please skip. this is a drag and drop. please skip.

that’s incorrect! ada and 508 are laws that require certain entities to create products that are accessible to everyone. wcag contains guidelines on how to meet the requirements. continue continue continue continue continue continue ada and 508 are laws that require certain entities to create products that are accessible to everyone. wcag contains guidelines on how to meet the requirements. that’s correct! continue continue continue continue continue continue b. ada b. ada b. ada b. ada b. ada b. ada c. wcag c. wcag c. wcag c. wcag c. wcag c. wcag which of the following only applies to federal agencies and those who receive federal funding? select one answer and then select submit. a. 508 a. 508 a. 508 a. 508 a. 508 a. 508 knowledge check submit submit submit submit submit submit

point #3 use of hands point #2 deaf, hard of hearing, or in a noisy room point #1 point #1 blah, blah, blah point #1 blind, low vision or in poor lighting developer notes give each button a title. click on the layer to add details and a possible icon, or in rare cases, an image. anything on the layer that is inside the circle needs a swivel transition. change outline to preferred color. sight sight sight sound sound sound mobility mobility mobility flip each round button to learn more. select each card to learn more. what is a physical disability? next slide next slide next slide next slide next slide next slide

that’s incorrect! 1 in 4 adults have a disability. continue continue continue continue continue continue 1 in 4 adults have a disability. that’s correct! continue continue continue continue continue continue select the statistic in the statement below and then select submit. submit submit submit submit submit submit
do your best it isn’t always practical to make every course completely accessible. the point is – do your best to make each course as accessible as your budget and time allows.

section 2 legal issues common mistakes focus order mistakes in section 2, we will cover legal issues. first we will review the common mistakes that are made that lead to lawsuits and then we will look exclusively at common focus order mistakes.

missing alt text for images and other graphics. missing navigation links and keyboard or screen reader traps. lacking screen reader functionality and efficiency. missing headings and titles. overusing links and missing link descriptions. developer notes you could start with some photographs along the bottom. we could also move the slider and add little icons or images instead of markers. each layer corresponds a marker. everything on the layer needs a fade animation. common legal issues you want to avoid these five common accessibility issues that are involved in lawsuits. move the slider to each position to learn more. you want to avoid these five common accessibility issues that are involved in lawsuits. overusing links and missing link descriptions missing headings and titles lacking screen reader functionality and efficiency missing navigation links and keyboard or screen reader traps missing alt text for images and other graphics

four focus order mistakes alt text decor layers videos leaving images as-is without any description. leaving decorative items in the fo not ordering layers and buttons giving separate controls for videos and leaving the video in the fo there are four common mistakes people make when adjusting their focus order. alternative text is missing from images. decorative content is not removed from the focus order. the layers are not in the proper focus order. videos are not removed from the focus order and they have separate controls.

section 3 e-learning accessibility suggestions text based supplements caption variable layer properties in this section, we will review how to turn your media into text, turn on the caption variable and configure layers to work with a screen reader.

five ways to turn content into text closed captions slide notes course transcript alternative text off-screen text boxes for sr developer notes change the image to a relevant photograph. to add the shape, go to format…picture shape. change the text lines. you can add or remove checkboxes/text and i can program them later. text boxes need a fade animation. keep buttons unclicked. select each checkbox to learn more.

srt are basic caption files. vtt files are more robust because they contain style codes for fonts, colors, weight, and alignment. there are two main types of captions. vtt vtt vtt vtt vtt vtt srt srt srt srt srt srt select each card to learn more. next slide next slide next slide next slide next slide next slide

turn on captions video setting: storyline software, slide edit mode silent video content: you should start each course with the captions on. if a user doesn’t want this accomodation, they can shut it off. select the variables icon, choose built-in and find the variable player.display captions and set it to true. by default, the accessible text will be true as well. if for some reason, it is false, then change it to true.

you can hide the base layer entirely. this will restrict the user from clicking objects on the base layer and it will make them invisible. you can hide the base layer entirely. this will restrict the user from clicking objects on the base layer and it will make them invisible. you will always want your layers to be placed directly after the button that shows them. no matter how you design your interaction, with a restricted base layer or a hidden base layer, you will always want your layers to be placed directly after the button that shows them. prevent users from clicking the base layer. for each layer, create a close button to hide the layer and return to the base layer. this will make it easiest for screen readers to navigate. you can pause the base layer if you have audio that plays on the base layer. if possible, prevent users from clicking the base layer. for each layer, create a close button to hide the layer and return to the base layer. this will make it easiest for screen readers to navigate. but that strategy won’t always work, like in this interaction. learners should have access to the base layer in order to make another selection. this makes it a bit more complicated for screen reader users. another tip to consider if you have audio on the base layer is to select the feature to pause the base layer. add alt text to both the normal and visited states of your buttons. you should always change the states of your buttons. the normal state can have alt text that is the same as the button label. in the above example, we have button labels of alt text, base layer, focus order, hiding base and so those can be entered as the normal state alt text. for the visited state, you simple add the word visited so visited alt text, visited base layer, visited focus order and visited hiding base. this way a screen reader will know which buttons they have already visited. to change the alt text for the normal state, right click the button and select the alt text field. then you can close. to change the visited state alt text, open the states and choose edit states. select the visited state, right click the button and add the term visited to the alt text field. alt text alt text alt text alt text alt text base layer base layer base layer base layer base layer base layer focus order focus order focus order focus order focus order focus order hiding layers hiding layers hiding layers hiding layers hiding layers hiding layers layers are used to create engaging interactions and they are a great way to break up large amounts of information. but layers can pose a problem in terms of accessibility. developer notes the initial screen will contain general information and the specific subtopics will be on each layer. we could add/remove buttons as needed and i can reprogram it later. when you are on a layer, you can use a downward arrow to show the objects on the main tl, use the eye to hide them. for example, you can hide the computer icon and that way you can insert a new picture on each layer. all objects on a layer need a fade transition. making layers accessible select each tab to learn a layer tip. next slide next slide next slide next slide next slide next slide
section 4 conclusion your opinion survey summary we will conclude this course with survey questions and a summary of what you have learned.

use the tab key or your mouse to navigate to this text field and then type your thoughts about accessibility. use the tab key again to exit the text field. w h a t d o y o u t h i n k ? what are your thoughts about accessibility?
strongly disagree 2 3 4 strongly agree every course should be wcag 2.1 aaa accessible. w h a t d o y o u t h i n k ? select your level of agreement with the following statement
there are very few disabled people who take online courses. strongly disagree 2 3 4 strongly agree w h a t d o y o u t h i n k ? select your level of agreement with the following statement.

summary in this course, you learned why accessibility is important to consider when building e-learning courses. you know about common legal issues and how to avoid them by following best practice strategies based off the wcag standards.
thank you! for learning about accessibility!

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Hey! Do you wanna learn how to make your e-learning courses more accessible? Are you working on a course that needs to be 508 compliant? Does your course need to prevent discrimination based on ADA? Then this course is for you! In this course you’re going to learn about all the standards and how to implement them in Storyline. You’ll see specific examples and I’ll walk you through exactly what to do to make your courses are 508 compliant, which also meets the WCAG AA standards, which by default, will also make your course ADA compliant. I got resources. I got videos. I got tips and tricks. You need this course to take your career to the next level. Come on! Sign up now!" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
